tit.cmt: 対訳が間違っているのではないでしょうか。諸国牧は「しょくまき」ではなく「しょこくまき」が正しいようです。以下、すべて訂正しました。

sen.j: 諸国牧（しょこくまき）は、古代の日本において、兵部省により開発・管轄された牧場であり、主に軍馬や貴族への貢馬、駅伝などの供給源とされた。
sen.e: Shokumaki is a farm developed and controlled by Hyobusho (ministry of military) in ancient Japan, which mainly provided war-horses, horses presented to nobles and ekiden.

Shokokumaki is a farm developed and controlled by Hyobusho (ministry of military) in ancient Japan, which mainly provided war-horses, horses presented to nobles and ekiden (ekiba (horses for transportation of official travelers) and post horse).
sen.cmt: shokumaki → shokokumaki 最後の「駅伝」の注釈がありません。おそらく駅（うまや）にいる駅馬・伝馬のことを指していると思われます。それに従って注釈を加えました。 travellers → travelers に訂正しました。
sen.e: Shokokumaki is a farm developed and controlled by Hyobusho (ministry of military) in ancient Japan, which mainly provided war-horses, horses presented to nobles and ekiden (ekiba (horses for transportation of official travelers) and post horse).

sen.j: また、諸国牧から集められた馬牛を放し飼いにするため、近都牧（きんとまき）と呼ばれる牧が九州や畿内周辺に設置された。
sen.e: In order to let horses and cows gathered from shokumaki run loose, farms called kintomaki were established in Kyushu and around the Kinai region.

sen.j: 本稿では、諸国牧と近都牧について記す。
sen.e: This article describes shokumaki and kintomaki.

sen.j: 官牧には、ほかに内厩寮が経営していた勅旨牧がある。
sen.e: Another kind of official farm is chokushimaki, managed by Naikyuryo (Bureau of administration of barn in the imperial court, the emperor's horses and the pasture).

sen.j: 諸国牧・近都牧がいつ設置されたのかは定かではないが、飛鳥時代の頃だと考えられている。
sen.e: It is not clear when shokumaki and kintomaki were established, but it is believed that they were established around the Asuka Period.

sen.cmt: shokumaki → shokokumaki period を大文字にする必要はないと考え、Asuka period に訂正しました。
sen.e: It is not clear when shokokumaki and kintomaki were established, but it is believed that they were established around the Asuka period.

sen.j: 諸国牧は、兵部省が所轄する牧で、延喜式によると18ヵ国に馬牧が24ヵ所、牛牧が12ヵ所、馬牛牧が3ヵ所の計39の牧が設置され、毎年、各牧から馬は5歳に達したものが左右馬寮に送られ、西海道諸国の牧からは大宰府に送られた。
sen.e: Shokumaki is a farm controlled by Hyobusho, and according to "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) 24 horse farms, 12 cow farms and 3 horse-cow farms, totaling in 39 farms, were established in 18 provinces, each of which sent horses that have reached the age of five to Sayu Meryo (the right and left divisions of Meryo, the bureau of horses) every year, while farms in various districts along the Saikaido Road sent horses to Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region).

sen.cmt: shokumaki → shokokumaki 初出のため、兵部省の注釈を加えました。

sen.j: この諸国から貢上された馬牛を放し飼いにする為に設けられたのが近都牧で、主に九州・近畿周辺に設置された。
sen.e: In order to let those horses and cows sent from various districts run loose, kintomaki was established mainly in Kyushu and around the Kinki region.

sen.j: 律令制下においては、各牧には、牧の責任者の牧長（ぼくちょう）1名、文書事務にあたる牧帳（まきちょう）1名がおかれ、ウマウシ100頭ごとに牧子（ぼくし）二名で飼育にあたり、国司が牧長以下らを指揮・監督していた。
sen.e: Under the ritsuryo system, one bokucho (official responsible for maki) and one makicho, who was in charge of clerical work, were assigned to each farm, two makiko per one hundred horses/cows were appointed to keep them, and bokucho and his men were subject to instruction and supervision of Kokushi (provincial governor).

Under the ritsuryo system, one bokucho, who was responsible for maki, and one makicho, who was in charge of clerical work, were assigned to each farm, two bokushi per one hundred horses/cows were appointed to take care of them, and bokucho and his subordinates were subject to instruction and supervision of Kokushi (provincial governor).
sen.cmt: 「牧長」と「牧帳」の注釈の書き方を統一しました。 「牧子」の読み方は「まきこ」ではなく「ぼくし」のようですので、訂正しました。 keep だけでは「飼育する」というニュアンスが出ないので、take care of に変更しました。 「牧長以下」をbokucho and his men とするのは少々カジュアルな印象を受けるので、bokucho and his subordinates としました。
sen.e: Under the ritsuryo system, one bokucho, who was responsible for maki, and one makicho, who was in charge of clerical work, were assigned to each farm, two bokushi per one hundred horses/cows were appointed to take care of them, and bokucho and his subordinates were subject to instruction and supervision of Kokushi (provincial governor).

sen.j: 中央では、兵馬司が、全国の牧と公私の馬牧を管理し、牧で乗馬に適するものは、軍団に送り裕福な兵士の家で飼育され、駄馬は、駅伝場として使用されるなど、国家によって騎馬の供給管理を統制するための仕組みがつくられていた。
sen.e: In the central government Hyomachi (Office of Military Horses) controlled farms all over Japan as well as public and private horse farms, and there was a system for governmental control over provision and management of riding horses, in which horses in the farms fit for riding were sent to the army and kept at a rich soldier's house and packhorses were used for ekiden.

In the central government Hyomashi (Office of Military Horses) controlled farms all over Japan as well as public and private horse farms, and there was a system for governmental control over provision and management of riding horses, in which horses in the farms fit for riding were sent to the army and kept at a rich soldier's house and the other horses were used for ekiden.
sen.cmt: スペルミス： Hyomachi → Hyomashi に訂正しました。 駄馬の意味でpackhorseが使われていますが、packhorse にはすでに荷馬という意味があり、この原文の場合は「乗馬に適さない馬」という意味なので、the other horses に置き換えました。
sen.e: In the central government Hyomashi (Office of Military Horses) controlled farms all over Japan as well as public and private horse farms, and there was a system for governmental control over provision and management of riding horses, in which horses in the farms fit for riding were sent to the army and kept at a rich soldier's house and the other horses were used for ekiden.

sen.j: なお、牧長・牧帳・牧子らが牧の経営にあたり、放牧中の馬を痩せさせたり、失ったり、あるいは、母蓄100頭に対して駒犢60頭という規定の増産数に達しない場合は、罰せられ、規定以上に駒犢を増やすことができれば、褒美として稲が与えられた。
sen.e: Bokucho, makicho and makiko, while managing the farm, were punished when free-range horses became thin or got lost, or when the prescribed goal of increase (60 ponies per 100 mares) is not attained, and were given rice as rewards when more ponies were produced than prescribed.

Bokucho, makicho and bokushi, while managing the farm, were punished when they got free-range horses thin or lost, or when the prescribed goal of increase (60 ponies per 100 mares) was not attained, and they were given rice as rewards when more ponies were produced than prescribed.
sen.cmt: makiko → bokushi に訂正しました。 文をすっきりさせるため、when 以下の主語をfree-range horses から牧長らを指すthey に変更し、後に続く部分もそれにしたがって変更しました。is not attained の時制を was not attained に訂正しました。and were ～と始まる部分を、よりわかりやすくするために、主語のthey を加えました。
sen.e: Bokucho, makicho and bokushi, while managing the farm, were punished when they got free-range horses thin or lost, or when the prescribed goal of increase (60 ponies per 100 mares) was not attained, and they were given rice as rewards when more ponies were produced than prescribed.
